I got confused with 100 tons = 90,700 kg.

a 'ton' is a North American short ton (US ton) 907.18474 kg (2,000 lbs).
an 'imperial ton' is a British long ton (1,016.047 kg or 2,240 lbs).
a 'metric ton' is a tonne (1,000 kg or 2,204.6 lbs).

As a Marine EOD Technician I was blessed to spend 3 years supporting many operations on the island of Kaho'olawe when it was used as a live training area, and also when live fire on the island was stopped in support of cleanup/sweep operations to remove unexploded ordnance. The crater created by the detonation of 500 tons starting at 3:28 on the video, on the island is affectionately known by EOD as Sailor's Hat, I cut my EOD teeth on that island learning up close and personal the many types of ordnance that were dropped, shot, or projected from days gone by, a great learning experience for me. Spent many days per month supporting Marine ops, sweeps, blowing holes for tree planting, and escorts of visiting authorized civilian personnel. I was also blessed to spend many days there with one of my EOD brothers for training, and just 2 Seabees down at smugglers cove while we were bivouacked at our hooch at LZ Seagull - 4 souls on the whole island - felt as if we owned the place. So many good memories there sitting on huge rocks outside our hooch watching the humpback whales breaching, with Lanai, Molokai, and Maui in the backdrop. Flying around with Tom Hauptman escorting a vet out into, in and around the impact areas when the last goats were still there roaming around. Was on the first team to return as a civilian EOD operator to begin the enormous undertaking with many others to rid the island of unexploded ordnance and all traces of human intrusion, with the exception of the Hawaiian ancestors and their artifacts which are sacred to the island, and the Hawaiian people. I was proud to have done my part to help heal the island, it is a very special place to me. It's a beautiful place, and I wanted to share this story. So many more stories I could speak of. To my active duty EOD brothers during that time '87-'90 , you know who you are, bless you all, and to all EOD operators past and present who earned the privilege to wear the Crab, God Bless and keep you in his care...as we say, "Initial Success or Total Failure" This story is dedicated to the 1st. MEB, BSSG-1 Marine EOD Team, and the Joint EOD team MCAS Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii - Ferg....

Correction: Propellant burns slowly when not confined under pressure. When confined under great pressure, it burns at a much higher velocity, actually detonates at a lower velocity, probably on the order of 6000 FPS.

Nearly all Supernovas are so powerful that they gravitationally collapse the core of a star either to a sphere the diameter of a metropolitan area called a neutron star, or completely collapse it into a zeroeth dimension object we know as a black hole.

But the biggest explosion in the universe where pure energy is emitted, with no gravitational collapse is a Carbon Detonation. A white dwarf mostly made of carbon accretes 1.4 times the mass of the sun. It’s core becomes so dense electrons, which create a force in response to the state of degeneracy they are in, are no longer capable of staying apart. But before it can collapse, fusion begins to occur but with no gravity to keep the white dwarf together, generates a thermonuclear explosion, a nuke, equivalent of 47.8 decillion tons. All pure energy enough to incinerate the solar system!

Vsauce, you make two errors.  The definition of a detonation is when the flame front speed IN THE EXPLOSIVE MEDIA is greater than the sound speed in the explosive media.  Not the sound speed in the gaseous products.  Second, even a deflagration can cause a shock wave in the medium into which it explodes.  For instance, the bullet coming out of the muzzle of a high powered rifle can exceed the speed of sound in air, and there can be an associate shock wave following behind the bullet.

Facts about Tsar Bomba:

The pilots who dropped the bomb would have travelled 45 km before the explosion, and were still given only 50% chance of survival.

The yield was 50 MT of TNT, which is approximately equal to 58 billion kWh. This is enough to power 1 million average American houses for more than 5 years.

The shockwave caused window panes to be partially broken up to a distance of 900 km.

The mushroom cloud was 95 km wide and 67 km tall (it extended into the mesosphere).

All buildings in a village located 55 km from the explosion were destroyed.

Anyone as far as 100 km from the blast would have gotten third degree burns from the heat.

Nice video. I see it was made some years ago, but the phrase "smokeless powder does not even detonate", it is only true if used in a gun. Smokeless powder is nitro-cellulose and often balanced with nitroglycerin, known as double-base powder.

Anyway, if you get enough smokeless powder and melt it with acetone and put a detonator (blasting cap) inside, it will surely detonate. Not because of the nitroglycerine contents and not because of the acetone, but simply because nitro-cellulose is detonable. You just need the correct amount and it must be in one whole grain and not in very small pieces like the one used in bullet shells.

You are wrong about that gunpowder does not detonate.
If you ignite gunpowder on a surface out in the air it will deflagrate.
Allso If you ignite gunpowder inside a weakly confined space, the gunpowder will deflagrate.
If you, on the other hand, ignite gunpowder inside a strongly confined space, the gunpowder will detonate.

The reason for this is that the more pressure you build up in the combustion, the faster the combustion will become.
In open air, there’s not much chance for a gunpowder combustion to build up enough pressure to reach a supersonic combustion.
In a weakly confined space (like in a bullet cartridge) the pressure will build up until the confinement breaks (the bullet is pushed out of the cartridge) bur after that the pressure will stop rising and not reaching numbers where gunpowder starts detonating.
In a strong confinement, however, the combustion will start as a deflagration but when the pressure is high enough, it will turn to a detonating combustion.

As I remember it, Tsar Bomba was not detonated high to reduce damage at ground level...it was to ENHANCE it. You detonate nukes at higher altitudes because the closer to the ground, the more of the energy just gets reflected upward and is wasted. When exploded high you get a much larger lateral component of the shock wave and thermal pulse and a lot more widespread ground damage. Tsar Bomba's reflected shock wave actually prevented the fireball from touching the ground, that speaks to the power of that aspect of that explosion. When you get to nukes that size, the overpressure created is a much more useful destructive element than the fireball.

There's some misinformation in this old video at 2:52 . Deflagration can produce shockwaves. The speed of sound relevant to deflagration or detonation is the speed of sound in the explosive material , not the speed of sound in air. You are not correct (in part). The defining factors of “detonation” don’t necessarily hinge on whether or not the reaction propagates at above the speed of sound, but rather more importantly if the shockwave (pressure wave) itself through decomposition is what is creating the energy necessary to sustain the reaction. Deflagration implies that heat alone is the catalyst (usually rapid oxidation). Firecrackers exploding and guns firing are both examples of deflagration reactions PROPAGATING FASTER THAN THE SPEED OF SOUND, and not detonation... though the primer that ignites the gunpowder within the case is detonated by the impact of the firing pin pinching the explosive compound in between the anvil and the inner portion of the primer wall :)

low and high explosives are classified by the speed of the reaction front in the reactive material, not the speed of the gasses produced.

If the reaction moves through the material at a rate lower than the speed of sound in that material, its deflagration.

If the reaction front (in this case also a shock front) moves through the material at a rate equal to or higher than the speed of sound in that material, it is detonation.

The speed of sound in solids and liquids is much, much higher than in the atmosphere, and the evolution or behavior of gasses in the reaction is irrelevant.

In Pakistani Army's war scenario planning sessions, one of the the scenarios was the Indian Army getting closer to the centre of the city of Lahore. The Pakistan Army's plan was to evacuate Lahore beforehand and detonate a small nuclear warheard, very much like the last clip in the video (to minimise fallout). This would deter the on coming Indian Army and hopefully intiate talks or a ceasefire. Ofcourse if that doesn't work, the bigger bombs are always there. However what cold war has taught us is that nuclear powers wage wars through proxies in the form of militants and insurgencies, not directly.

What's more unnerving is the fact that the Tsar Bomba was actually scaled back from its full design capacity. In brief, it used a conventional nuclear explosion to set off a second stage, and larger, nuclear explosion. That, in turn, was used to set off the final third stage. No it is not possible. The theory of special relativity states that as an object accelerates, its energy increases and you approach infinite energy the closer you get to light speed, thus for an object (such as the gas in an explosion) to achieve light speed itself, it would need infinite energy and naturally that is simply not possible. And to go further, an object going faster than the speed of light would require more than infinite amount of energy, which is equally impossible.

Cool vid, I just wanted to say that supernovas are not the biggest explosions. A supernova is a supergiant star exploding, a star 10 to 70 times as massive as the sun. Hypernovae are hypergiant stars exploding, stars 100 to 300 times more massive than our sun. Hypernovae are at least 100 times stronger than a supernova, with some producing 10^48 joules in raw energy. They're so strong that they eject two jets of pure plasma at nearly the speed of light.
